docs.title: Welcome
docs.text: Welcome to my documentation site for the Foundations of Modeling & Fabrication course. This site documents my journey through digital modeling, fabrication processes, and design thinking.

docs.title: About Me
docs.text: Name: Your Name Background: Postgraduate in IoT Embedded Systems Focus: Applying computational thinking to physical design and fabrication

docs.title: Course Overview
docs.text:
This course explores the intersection of digital modeling and physical fabrication, covering:

  • Geometric and parametric modeling
  • Digital fabrication methods (additive, subtractive, formative)
  • Material behavior and constraints
  • Prototyping as research
  • Design-to-fabrication workflows

docs.title: Site Navigation
docs.text:
• Digital Modeling - My modeling approach, tools, and workflows
  • Fabrication Logic - Machines, materials, and constraints
  • Prototyping & Iteration - Tests, failures, and improvements
  • Reflection - Critical analysis and lessons learned

"Design and making are inseparable."

Documentation Note

This site is built using MkDocs with the Material theme. All content is written in Markdown and version-controlled on GitHub.

docs.title: Tolerances & Constraints
docs.text:
Key Learnings:

Tolerance Planning

  • Add 0.2mm clearance for snap-fit parts
  • Account for material shrinkage in 3D prints
  • Test fit before final fabrication

Machine Limitations: - Laser cutter: Max thickness 6mm - 3D printer: Build volume 200x200x200mm - CNC: Minimum feature size 1mm

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
Before DFM: Issues: Overhangs, unsupported features

After DFM: Improvements: Self-supporting, printable orientation

docs.title: Safety & Best Practices
docs.text:
• Always use protective equipment
  • Understand machine operation before use
  • Material safety data sheets (MSDS) review
  • Proper ventilation for laser cutting

docs.title: Philosophy
docs.text:
"Failure is a learning tool"

Prototypes serve as research tools and assumption tests in the design inquiry process.

docs.title: Iteration Cycle
docs.text:
graph TD
    A[Hypothesis] --> B[Prototype v1]
    B --> C[Test]
    C --> D{Success?}
    D -->|No| E[Analyze Failure]
    D -->|Yes| F[Document & Refine]
    E --> G[Redesign]
    G --> B
    F --> H[Final Design]

docs.title: Prototype 1: Initial Concept
docs.text:
Goal: Test basic form and fit

Method: Rapid 3D print with low infill

Results: - ✅ Form validated - ❌ Structural weakness at joint - ❌ Tolerance too tight for assembly

Images:

First iteration - identified structural issues

docs.title: Prototype 2: Structural Refinement
docs.text:
Changes Made: - Increased wall thickness from 2mm to 3mm - Added ribbing for reinforcement - Adjusted clearances to +0.3mm

Results: - ✅ Improved strength - ✅ Better assembly fit - ⚠️ Weight increased 15%

docs.title: Prototype 3: Material Exploration
docs.text:
Experiment: Testing different materials

Material Strength Flexibility Cost Result PLA Medium Low Low Brittle failure PETG High Medium Medium ✅ Best option TPU Low High High Too flexible

docs.title: Final Prototype
docs.text:
Refinements: - Material: PETG - Optimized geometry based on stress testing - Final tolerances documented

Final iteration ready for production

docs.title: Test 1: Structural Load
docs.text: Setup: [Describe test method] Load Applied: [Specify] Result: [Pass/Fail with data]

docs.title: Test 2: Assembly Time
docs.text: Metric: Time to assemble components Target: < 5 minutes Actual: 3 minutes 45 seconds ✅

docs.title: Failures & Learnings
docs.text:
Major Failure: Snap-fit Breakage

What happened: Clips broke during assembly Root cause: Insufficient draft angle Fix: Redesigned with 5° draft, thicker base Lesson: Always prototype assembly mechanisms first

Material Warping

What happened: Large flat surfaces warped during printing Root cause: Inadequate bed adhesion, cooling Fix: Added brim, enclosed printer, slower cooling Lesson: Large parts need environmental control

docs.title: Key Insights
docs.text:
1. Prototype early and often - catching issues early saves time
  2. Test one variable at a time - isolate what causes success/failure
  3. Document everything - patterns emerge from detailed notes
  4. Embrace failure - each failure teaches more than success

docs.title: Course Learnings
docs.text: This course fundamentally changed how I think about the relationship between digital design and physical fabrication.

docs.title: Key Realizations
docs.text:
1. Fabrication is a Design Choice

Before this course, I viewed fabrication as simply "making what was designed." Now I understand that the fabrication method actively shapes what can be designed. The constraints of 3D printing, laser cutting, or CNC milling aren't limitations—they're design parameters.

2. Materials Have Agency

Coming from electronics/IoT, I was used to treating enclosures as afterthoughts. This course taught me that materials actively influence outcomes through their properties, behavior, and constraints. Designing with materials rather than despite them leads to better results.

3. Iteration is Research

Each prototype isn't just a step toward a final product—it's an experiment that generates knowledge. Failed prints taught me more about design tolerances than any textbook could.

docs.title: Connections to IoT/Embedded Systems
docs.text:
As an IoT engineer, this course revealed surprising parallels:

IoT/Embedded Concept Modeling/Fabrication Parallel Debugging firmware Iterating on physical prototypes Circuit tolerances Fabrication tolerances PCB design rules Design for manufacturability System integration Assembly design Power constraints Material/process constraints

Key Connection: Both fields require designing within constraints while finding creative solutions.

docs.title: What Worked Well
docs.text: ✅ Parametric thinking - My programming background made parametric modeling intuitive ✅ Systematic testing - Debugging mindset helped in prototype iteration ✅ Documentation habits - Already practiced from technical writing

docs.title: What Was Challenging
docs.text: ⚠️ Material intuition - Understanding how materials behave physically (vs. digitally) ⚠️ Aesthetic judgment - Moving beyond pure function to consider form ⚠️ Machining experience - Physical tool operation was new territory

docs.title: Technical Skills
docs.text:
• Parametric CAD modeling
  • 3D printing workflow (design → slice → print → post-process)
  • Laser cutting operations
  • Design for manufacturability principles
  • Material selection based on properties

docs.title: Conceptual Skills
docs.text:
• Thinking through fabrication constraints during design
  • Iterative prototyping methodology
  • Critical evaluation of design decisions
  • Balancing form, function, and feasibility

docs.title: Critical Questions Encountered
docs.text:
"Should everything that can be made, be made?"

This question resonated deeply. As someone who can now design and fabricate rapidly, I have responsibility to consider:

  • Material waste: Is this iteration necessary, or am I over-prototyping?
  • Energy consumption: 3D printing is energy-intensive—when is it justified?
  • Longevity: Am I designing for disposability or durability?
  • Repairability: Can this be fixed, or must it be replaced?

docs.title: Personal Commitments
docs.text:
Moving forward, I commit to:

  1. Design for disassembly - making repair/upgrade possible
  2. Minimize material waste - careful planning before fabrication
  3. Choose sustainable materials when performance allows
  4. Document and share - so others can learn without repeating my failures

docs.title: In IoT/Embedded Work
docs.text:
I will apply these learnings to:

  • Better enclosure design for sensors and devices
  • Integrated design where electronics and housing are co-designed
  • Rapid prototyping of hardware concepts
  • Custom fixturing for assembly and testing

docs.title: Personal Projects
docs.text:
Ideas sparked by this course:

  • Parametric enclosure generator for common PCB sizes
  • Modular sensor mounting system
  • Custom test fixtures for embedded development

docs.title: Final Thoughts
docs.text:
"Design and making are inseparable."

This statement from Day 1 felt abstract initially. After completing this course, I understand it viscerally. The best designs emerge from a dialogue between digital intent and physical reality—neither can exist in isolation.

Most valuable lesson: Constraints aren't obstacles; they're the creative medium. Just as a haiku's 5-7-5 structure forces linguistic creativity, fabrication constraints force design innovation.
